context.text: What's the reason--

context.text: Having read this enlightening opinion of Justice Scalia in Freytag, which is enlightening to me if I've read it correctly, I would say that the question -- there are two separate questions.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And what we found in our office was thousands of positions arguably occupied by a person who seems to be an inferior officer of the United States, and who is protected by two levels of double clause including for example high level administrators of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, The Federal Trade Commission, The Federal Communications Commission, The Chemical Safety Board, The Federal Mine Safety And Health Review Commission, The Social Security Administration and including as well 1500 administrative law judges and including might be surprised, -- I was surprised to hear this, most of the military's officer core, they all have two levels of protection and they are all officers of the United States.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: So what's supposed to happen, when a private company that opposes an agency decision, attacks the constitutionality of that decision on grounds similar to the ground advanced by the private company in this case?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The majority just says, well this may be really different but maybe it is, I just don’t see it at the moment and I wish they had, well, the majority does not explain whether or how these positions differ from most of the county board members before us, but unless today's principle of constitutional law is limited in some way or other, it can become virulent, running like a computer virus throughout the holes of government.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I cannot know for certain for the reasons that the Chief Justice said, just what the adverse consequences of today's new principles will be, but I fear and I have grounds for fear, that they may be substantial, that concern helps explain why, joined by Justice Stevens, Justice Ginsburg and Justice Sotomayor, I dissent.

context.text: --He -- he admitted to the police, and I don't want to get too much into the facts, but that -- but even if Your Honor concedes that he was convicted of all those crimes, which he was not convicted of, but the judge, as you say, correctly relied upon for this sentence, then we only have two States that we know of that have imposed life without parole for a recidivist robbery or burglary crime, and that's California and Florida.

context.speaker: Bryan S. Gowdy
context.text: And we -- we've set forth that argument to give the Court that option, but we believe our primary argument, the categorical rule, is more logical because of the fact that you can't do a case-by-case determination of an adolescent at the time -- based on his juvenile offense.

context.text: So why isn't that subject to arbitration by the very terms of the arbitration clause?

context.speaker: Robert Bonsall
context.text: --We think that there's still an issue that is being sent to the arbitrator, the breach of contract and damages, but as a precursor to that, we contend that the issue never should have been litigated at all by the trial court about whether there was formation, because there was no question of formation at that time.

context.text: I thought you answered Justice Alito "no", but I thought his question was a very simple one.

context.text: You're taking the position, I think, that there's no dispute that on -- in December a contract was formed.

context.text: Absolutely correct, Your Honor.

context.text: The employer is alleging that there is a breach of the no-strike clause.

context.text: The union is alleging a defense to that allegation by asserting a meritsbased issue regarding whether, in a certain narrow gap period, falling in between the effective date of the contract--

context.text: And so, consequently, if we accepted the position of the international, you would create a no-man's zone that would apply throughout this country, whereby collective bargaining agreements entered into by locals could be destroyed, violated, by an international that would choose to impose itself on the local and cause that to happen.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Sotomayor has the opinion this morning in case 08-1119, Milavetz, Gallop, & Milavetz versus All State Insurance and the consolidated case.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: With limited exceptions, the bankruptcy abuse Prevention and Consumer Protection Act of 2005 defines the term debt relief agency to include any person who provides bankruptcy assistance to an assisted person for payment or who is a bankruptcy petition for payer.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Or do you say there should be an interlocutory appeal there?

context.speaker: Randall L.  Allen
context.text: --Your Honor, we do not argue that -- here, that there should be an interlocutory appeal for trade secrets.

context.speaker: Randall L.  Allen
context.text: I think the practical resolution to the trade secret question is present in most cases of commercial litigation, where the court would provide a protective order limiting access to the trade secret; in other words, limiting access to counsel.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: But what if the court doesn't, as Justice Scalia has posited?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: The court here could do the same thing, depending on the secret being disclosed.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: It could set up any number of protective mechanisms.

context.speaker: Randall L.  Allen
context.text: I don't think 1292 would -- would obtain, in this instance, and I think the -- the judge in the district court made this observation himself, although he did not expound on his reasoning.

context.speaker: Randall L.  Allen
context.text: It would appear that the reasoning would be that this -- that a decision in this case is not likely to materially advance the ultimate determination of the litigation, so, therefore, I think 1292(b) would not be applicable in the ordinary case to a -- to a ruling finding waiver of the attorney-client privilege.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Why do you think that your -- that this privilege -- or is it -- more important than any other privilege?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I mean, Justice Scalia's question and your answer convinced me that you can protect this the same as you can any other trade secret -- any trade secret.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Of course, you do disclose it to the opposing party, but that is also true of any breach of any privilege, so husband-wife, priest-penitent, psychiatrist and patient.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I take all of those are privileged.

context.speaker: Randall L.  Allen
context.text: I think access to information in the course of discovery does not trigger the same important interest that orders compelling discovery of attorney-client would trigger?

context.speaker: Randall L.  Allen
context.text: So I don't think that they would in any way satisfy that test.

context.speaker: Randall L.  Allen
context.text: And I think, in fact, the question presented as designed even by Respondent does not capture orders that deny the disclosure of attorney-client privilege information.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Some time ago Justice Breyer asked the question of why is this different than the other privileges, and I would like your answer to that.

context.speaker: Randall L.  Allen
context.text: Justice Breyer, I think that the answer to that question has to focus on the role that the privilege plays in the administration of justice, and it's why I went, in response to Justice Sotomayor's question, why I went to the balancing between the interest of the attorney-client privilege versus the interest of a more rigorous application of the final judgment rule.

context.speaker: Randall L.  Allen
context.text: So -- so, while I think it is instructive to compare the privilege to other privileges that the Court may in the future confront, I think the proper analysis is to balance that, that rigorous application of the final judgment rule, to the attorney-client privilege.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: In case 08-678 Mohawk Industries Incorporated versus Carpenter, Justice Sotomayor has the opinion of the Court.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Section 1291 of the judicial code confers on federal courts of appeals jurisdiction to review final decisions of the district courts.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Although the final decisions typically are ones that trigger the entry of judgment, we have recognized that they also include a small class of Prejudgment orders that resolve important questions collateral to the merits of an action and are effectively unreviewable on appeal from final judgment.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: In short, the benefits of extending the collateral order doctrine to attorney-client privilege rulings are likely to be minimal while the cost might well be significant.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Authorizing litigants to pursue successive piecemeal appeals of all such rulings which disrupt the orderly progress of ongoing litigation and needlessly burden the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Accordingly we affirm the judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Justice Thomas concurs in part and concurs in the judgment.

context.text: Most critically, the DC circuit's confinement of Mobile-Sierra to challenges by contracting parties defeats the doctrine's animating purpose, promotion of the stability of supply arrangements which all agree is essential to the health of the energy industry.

context.text: That would not, under your argument, entitle the court to give an enhancement?

context.speaker: Mark H. Cohen
context.text: --No, it wouldn't, Your Honor, because, if that $200-an-hour associate was doing other work for other clients, the bill would be for $200 an hour, regardless of what the result would have been or how good that associate would have been.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Mr. Cohen, you said in your brief that, in such a case, the prevailing party could argue that counsel should obtain a higher hourly rate in the litigation than the customary rate he or she charges in other cases, and that's the situation Justice Sotomayor inquired about.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But that sounds to me -- you take the second-year associate, pay him at the rate of the top partner because her performance was so outstanding.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: That's an enhancement, but it isn't as transparent as the one that Judge Shoob gave.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: He performed like a 15-year lawyer.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: The difference is not with respect to skill and experience.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: It's with respect to performance.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: And so what Justice Ginsburg was asking is, what you are basically saying, the quality of that representation, even though it reflected more than the market one would look at objectively on the basis of the years of experience, that judge can't enhance, even though someone performed far above whatever else the market would consider his or her skills at the moment.

context.speaker: Mark H. Cohen
context.text: --Well, remember, Your Honor, that, when the statute was enacted, it was said in the congressional reports that they wanted to compensate for the expenditure of time and to reimburse the plaintiff, if you will, for what the plaintiff put out in terms of expenses and fees.

context.speaker: Mark H. Cohen
context.text: Well, if you are -- if you are going to basically treat that second-year associate as a 15-year partner and award him a $500-an-hour rate, what you are actually doing is overcompensating that person for what the expenditure of time was and for what the actual fee they would have charged to their client was.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Does that mean that, even if we were dealing with police officers who did what the prosecutors were alleged to have done at the investigation stage, no prosecutor, only police investigators, the fact that a trial and a conviction had occurred would mean that the police officers were not liable, either?

context.speaker: Stephen Sanders
context.text: Your Honor, the fact that a trial and conviction had occurred could mean that the police officers were liable because of the due process violation at the trial, but in footnote 5 of Buckley, this Court was very clear and insisted that there is no disjunction between observing that a prosecutor, like a police officer, has only qualified immunity during the investigation while, at the same time, insisting that that does not affect the fact that the prosecutor has absolute--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Take two cases.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: One is Justice Ginsburg's case, a police officer fabricates the evidence, dupes the prosecuting attorney, or -- or doesn't fully disclose.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Case two, a prosecutor does the same thing and gives it to a fellow prosecutor.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Same -- should the analysis be precisely the same?

context.speaker: Stephen Sanders
context.text: The courts below wrongfully abrogated trial immunity because trial is the only place where the injury of conviction and subsequent incarceration could have taken place.

context.speaker: Stephen Sanders
context.text: Without reference to that specific injury, there is simply no other injury.

context.speaker: Stephen Sanders
context.text: The--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I'm not sure that I fully grasp your answer to my first question and to Justice Kennedy's, that is, yes or no, if everything that happened was alleged to have happened, but it was done by a police officer or a different prosecutor, nonetheless, the trial went on, the fabricated evidence was introduced, without any participation by the actual prosecutor in that fabrication, does a conviction -- does the -- do the police officers or the prosecutors that was not involved in the trial get absolute -- are they -- are they no more liable, not because they have absolute immunity, but because the trial and conviction at which the evidence was used overtakes what liability they might have had, absent the trial?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Is that your position?

context.speaker: Stephen Sanders
context.text: --Your Honor, our position is -- I believe I would agree with you.

context.speaker: Stephen Sanders
context.text: As the United States explains in its brief, for a police officer to be held liable in those circumstances, it would need to be under some sort of malicious prosecution theory that would depend on the actual conviction and the use of the evidence at trial.

context.speaker: Stephen Sanders
context.text: But the use of the evidence at trial is the injury itself, and that is exclusively a prosecutorial act, only a prosecutor could--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You're not answering the question clearly.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Are both the prosecutor, in Justice Ginsburg's hypothetical, and the policeman liable?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Can't you answer that?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Yes or no.

context.speaker: Stephen Sanders
context.text: --The -- the odd thing about -- if we are taking out reference to the trial itself, then there simply can be no claim.

context.speaker: Stephen Sanders
context.text: Respondents urge a new freestanding right, separate and apart from the due process trial right, yet at the same time--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But you said that there -- that there would be liability, as long as it wasn't the same person involved in the investigation and the trial.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Even though there had been a trial, you say -- you answered Justice Scalia, that those people separated from the trial would be liable, even though there was a trial, and it's at issue.

context.speaker: Stephen Sanders
context.text: --Your Honor, looking to the common law, the rationale for that would be a form of malicious prosecution, but as you observed in your concurrence in Albright, asserting malicious prosecution against a prosecutor would be anomalous because it's the prosecutor who is exclusively responsible for causing the kind of injury.

context.speaker: Stephen Sanders
context.text: If a police officer or a nonprosecuting prosecutor simply fabricates the evidence, as Chief Judge Easterbrook of the Seventh Circuit said, there can be no cause of action.

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: Well, I do think that there is a debate in the briefs before this Court, including the brief by 12,400 or so prosecutors that takes the reverse view.

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: But be that as it may, I think that is a question for the legislature.

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: This Court has said repeatedly that those ethics and disciplinary violations are -- are a successful deterrent, and there is others as well that this Court has pointed to that may be available, including counsel's liability.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, you can't have it both ways and say this is a policy we should take into account and then when Justice Sotomayor asks you a question, say: Oh, well, that's for the legislature.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I mean, you're -- it seems to me you're trying to have it both ways.

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: Well, with respect to a cause of action and whether the principles of absolute immunity apply to this, I think this Court has already recognized several times that the overriding interest is protecting the judicial process and not letting information be chilled and not come in.

context.speaker: Paul D. Clement
context.text: If I don't put it on into evidence and I come clean now, I'm actually liable for the arrest and all the pretrial detention.

context.speaker: Paul D. Clement
context.text: If I actually introduce it into evidence now, I'm scot-free.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: There's a different tendency, which I would say this is a slight fluke, what you're describing.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I'm more worried about what Justice Alito brought up, that, other things being equal, I think it's probably a good thing to get prosecutors involved in the questioning process.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: That -- that has a kind of check on the police.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And the concern I'd have is that the -- this will discourage the prosecutors from becoming involved in the witness -- witness questioning process, at least not before the police are well on the way.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: In other places, they do it a lot.

context.speaker: Paul D. Clement
context.text: --Well, I mean, another thing presumably, Justice Breyer, you want to encourage is having the police officers come to the prosecutors and get legal advice about what they're doing.

context.speaker: Paul D. Clement
context.text: And this Court squarely confronted that question in Burns and said the advice-giving function, which is a function only a prosecutor, only a lawyer anyways, can perform--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --Well, could you answer Justice Breyer's question, which I -- I think raises a -- a critical point in terms of Justice Alito's examples of talking to the witness.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Why isn't that at some point -- I think in Buckley, the "judicial phase".

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Why is this the judicial phase?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: In other places, they do it a lot.

context.speaker: Paul D. Clement
context.text: --Well, I mean, another thing presumably, Justice Breyer, you want to encourage is having the police officers come to the prosecutors and get legal advice about what they're doing.

context.speaker: Paul D. Clement
context.text: And this Court squarely confronted that question in Burns and said the advice-giving function, which is a function only a prosecutor, only a lawyer anyways, can perform--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --Well, could you answer Justice Breyer's question, which I -- I think raises a -- a critical point in terms of Justice Alito's examples of talking to the witness.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Why isn't that at some point -- I think in Buckley, the "judicial phase".

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Why is this the judicial phase?

context.speaker: Paul D. Clement
context.text: I mean, that is really an anomalous result, that it's the n anomaly that caused this Court in Buckley to draw the line at probable cause.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I was going to suggest in response to your point that -- you know, qualified immunity is really significant.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Of course, it is, but we've recognized, in a number of contexts, in the judicial area, for example, that it's -- it's not enough.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: We have also recognized that in the prosecutorial area, and trying to draw the line where you do -- I think this was one of the points Justice Alito was making, is that, sometimes, you're investigating and preparing your case at the same time.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: You don't just sit back and say, I'm -- I'm just going to look and see what I can find.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: You have particular areas.

context.speaker: Paul D. Clement
context.text: And, again, the Court addressed exactly this Court in the -- exactly that issue in the Buckley decision and said, sure -- you know, from -- with the benefit of hindsight, you can sort of retrospectively look and make anything in the investigatory stage part of -- and part and parcel of the prosecution.

context.speaker: Paul D. Clement
context.text: And I don't think that was something that this Court saw as a reason not to draw a clean line that's consistent with the functional approach.

context.speaker: Paul D. Clement
context.text: It's consistent, not just with Buckley, but with Burns and with Kalina and with a whole host of this Court's decisions.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: In -- in answer to Justice Breyer's question, would -- would it be a -- would it be practical and conceptually correct to draw the line at the stage at which the prosecutor is interviewing witnesses to evaluate credibility?

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: So, at that stage, the prosecutorial function has begun and absolute immunity would kick in.

context.speaker: Paul D. Clement
context.text: Well, if I could add, I mean, I suppose I might be able--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: No, just begin the formulation.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I'm -- I'm starting to prosecute this person, rather than saying, let's look, let's investigate, let's interview, and then decide who we're going to prosecute.

context.speaker: Paul D. Clement
context.text: --Well, I suppose--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: In Justice Alito's hypothetical, you've got a CFO, you can -- you know, you've probably got probable cause to go after him as well, but you want to begin interviewing him, to see if he's going to flip in your case against the CEO.

context.speaker: Paul D. Clement
context.text: --Well, if you have probable cause, then I think you're on the other side of the Buckley line, and that's an objective determination, and I think--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.

context.text: The Court of Appeal, therefore set aside the order, remanded the proceeding and certified to the Florida Supreme Court the question whether the Act unconstitutionally deprived Petitioner's Members of littoral rights without just compensation.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: The State Supreme Court answered “no” and quashed the remand, concluding that the Members did not own the property supposedly taken.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I will describe, first the holding of a plurality of the court in an opinion by Justice Scalia joined by me, Justice Thomas and Justice Alito.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Well, the classic thinking is a transfer of property to the state or to another private party by eminent domain, the Takings Clause applies to other state actions that achieve the same thing.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Thus we upheld that it is a taking, if the government recharacterize as public property what was previously private property.

context.speaker: Bryan A. Stevenson
context.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: Joe Sullivan was 13 years of age when he was arrested with two older boys, one 15 and one 17, charged with sexual assault, ultimately convicted, and sentenced to life without parole.

context.speaker: Bryan A. Stevenson
context.text: Joe is one of only two children this age who have ever been sentenced to life without parole for a non-homicide, and no child has received this sentence for non-homicide in the last 18 years.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Mr. Stevenson, there's a serious question before we get to the particulars of this case.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Justice Kennedy suggested it in the last argument.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: This -- the time ran out for postconviction relief in 1993, and this petition is brought in 2007.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: There's a 2-year statute of limitations.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I have lots of cases like that.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: What I wondered is if anybody found a case along the lines that I just said.

context.speaker: Thomas H.  Geoghegan
context.text: We did not, Your Honor, and the Wells case in particular, where there was no question that the rule was valid, was a case where the Fourth Circuit found a violation of due process because the parties did not have reasonable notice, or the carrier in that case did not have reasonable notice that it was the postage date that was the date for the brief, instead of the postmark.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Ginsburg has her opinion this morning in case 08-604, Union Pacific Railroad versus the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: This case concerns the Railway Labors Act's provisions for resolution of disputes between Railroads employees and their employers.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: It knows that those persons, if released, will commit serious sexual offenses; and it knows too that States are often not in a position to deal with such dangers, not in a position to take custody and care and responsibility for those persons upon release from Federal prison.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: This is essentially a transitional problem that the Court was -- that the Congress was dealing with, how to manage the transition from Federal custody to State superintendence and responsibility.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, is part of the statutory scheme that you can be committed to Federal custody for, say, a year and then the State takes it over?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: That is correct, Justice Kennedy.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: In fact, what the statute requires is for the Attorney General really to -- immediately upon commitment, to go to a State, if he hasn't done so beforehand -- to go to two States, the State of domicile and the State of prior conviction.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Why would a State want to incur that extra expense if--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: What was the experience under 4246?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: You pointed out that that has been on the books for some time, and there efforts must be made to have the State take the person.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: When the civil commitment is used following the end of a term -- let's say someone is insane -- how often does it end up that the State takes responsibility and how often is it that the person stays in Federal custody?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: --I think it is unusual, Justice Ginsburg.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: It's not the usual course that the State does take responsibility.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: But the Federal statute commits the Attorney General and the Bureau of Prisons to try to persuade a State to take custody, to defer to the State if a State has some reason to take custody, but -- but makes sure that the Federal Government is a kind of backstop, so that if the State does not take responsibility and does not take custody, the Federal Government will ensure that the person will not be released, the person who has been found to be both mentally ill and sexually--

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: But, again, the State always has the ability to come in and say: We would like to take control over this person.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: And more to the point, the Attorney General has the responsibility to keep going to the State and to try to see if he can transfer custody to the State.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: What -- what -- what power conferred upon the Federal Government by the Constitution permits the Federal Government to assure that sexual predators are not at large?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: I think the power, Justice Scalia, is the power to run a responsible criminal justice system, to run a criminal justice system that does not itself endanger the public.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: So you would say that the Federal Government has no such power independent of the criminal conviction?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: In other words, that Congress could not pass a law saying, just as this one says, we are going to commit people who are sexually dangerous until a determination that they are not or until the State can take them?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: --I think that the power to run a responsible criminal justice system extends to the way in which the Federal Government releases these prisoners.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: And--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Could the Federal Government order a commitment of anyone who's been in Federal custody over the last 10 years?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: --Justice Kennedy, I think that that would be a much harder case.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: There are some people, of course, who are on supervised release and, for example--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: No, no, no.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: So that must be because there is a lack of Federal power.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Yes, I think that that's correct, that at that point the State police power over a person has been fully reestablished.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But it's fully reestablished once he walks out of Federal prison, at least if he walks out of Federal prison into a State.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: I think that that's not right, Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: I think that there is a transition period, and what this statute is designed to do is to deal with that transition period and to make sure that sexually dangerous, mentally ill people don't fall through the cracks between Federal custody and the reestablishment of State control.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Well, but they don't fall through the cracks if the Federal Government notifies the State into which this prisoner is to be released: We are going to release a prisoner; we think he's sexually dangerous; you should take some action to be sure that he doesn't harm society.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Under your theory -- under the theory that you are proposing, then, any dangerous person, whether it's because of mental illness or any other reason, could be held indefinitely--

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: No--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: --under a civil commitment statute, because what you're saying is that the Federal Government, merely because of their -- their time in control of the individual, has an unlimited constitutional power to then civilly commit this dangerous person.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: --I think what would prevent that, Justice Sotomayor, is the Due Process Clause.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: It is obviously the case that there are other constraints on governmental action than Article I.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Well, what -- what constrains the government under the Due Process Clause from invoking a dangerousness merely because someone has a long history.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: --the connection between the nature of the mental illness and the constitutional power that you are claiming.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: What -- what is it that gives you that power?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: --Well, if you go back to a case like Kansas v. Hendricks, which is of course where this Court thought about civil commitment statutes with relation to sexually dangerous offenders, I think the Court made clear that it was important in that case that there be not only sexual dangerousness, but also mental illness, in order to invoke the civil commitment statutes.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Are you saying that as far as those limitations, the question that Justice Sotomayor was asking, the limitations on the Federal Government would be the same as they are on the States?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But that's a different question from whether the Federal Government has any power at all.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: You said it better than I did, Justice Ginsburg.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: --Well, if you go back to a case like Kansas v. Hendricks, which is of course where this Court thought about civil commitment statutes with relation to sexually dangerous offenders, I think the Court made clear that it was important in that case that there be not only sexual dangerousness, but also mental illness, in order to invoke the civil commitment statutes.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Are you saying that as far as those limitations, the question that Justice Sotomayor was asking, the limitations on the Federal Government would be the same as they are on the States?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But that's a different question from whether the Federal Government has any power at all.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: You said it better than I did, Justice Ginsburg.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: That's exactly right, that of course there are constraints on the Federal Government in using civil commitment statutes, that they are the same as the -- the constitutional constraints on the States when they use that power.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: But this is a different question.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You could say it's necessary for the good of society, but that's not what the Federal Government is charged with.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Why is it necessary to any function that the Federal Government is performing?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It has completed its performance of the function of incarcerating this individual until he has served his punishment.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: --The Court has always said, Justice Scalia, that the Necessary and Proper Clause, the question is, is it necessary and proper to the beneficial exercise of Federal powers?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: And so this is, that it is necessary and proper to the beneficial or, what I said before, the responsible exercise of the Federal power to operate a criminal justice system, which includes the responsibility to ensure that those people who have been in custody in that Federal -- in that criminal justice system are not released irresponsibly.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Isn't it the case that--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But the brief -- excuse me.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: --Well, I was going to ask, is it the case that the unwillingness of States to step into this area in these instances is a consequence, at least in part and perhaps in large part, of the Federal incarceration, that as a result of the Federal incarceration, the person is no longer viewed by the State as -- as having domicile within the State, the State of prior domicile has no way of knowing whether that person would return to a domicile in the prior State?

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Is that -- do you think that is a fair understanding of the reason for the enactment of this?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Just to make sure that I understand the question, that the reason for the enactment in part has to do with the fact that the Federal Government has assumed custodial responsibility and has disrupted the relationship between the State and the citizen, I think that that's exactly right, Justice Alito.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: But in some sense, it's not just that the Federal system finds itself in possession and custody of these people, but the Federal -- what Congress could reasonably find is that the Federal Government knows that there's nobody else to take appropriate custody and care and that the reason that there's nobody else to take appropriate custody and care has to do with the Federal action itself.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: So, is the prisoner--

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Section 4248 is identical in -- in all relevant constitutional respects to section 4246, which is the general civil commitment statute for mentally ill, dangerous people generally, not with any sexual--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: --But, General--

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: --component to it.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: --I understood you in your response to Justice Alito to say, if I remember, that it was not just the fact of Federal custody, but the fact that there are no States or there may well often be no States willing.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: What if every State is willing; I mean, every State is willing to take the people on out of a concern to protect their citizens.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Does that somehow mean there's no necessary and proper power?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: --Well, if -- if -- that's exactly right, that if the facts before Congress were such that there were no difficulty with this transition period and that nobody ever fell between the cracks, an entirely different question would be presented, and then there would be some kind of argument that at that point, in those circumstances State police power would be the appropriate default position.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: But--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: General Kagan, I -- I find it difficult to believe that if the Federal Bureau of Prisons wrote the governor of the State into which this person is to be released, and they try to release him in the State where he -- he will in the future reside, and said, we are about to release this person in 60 days or whatever, in our view there are serious mental problems, and we think the State ought to consider commitment proceedings, I find it difficult to believe that an elected governor or an elected attorney general would ignore that letter.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: --I do believe, Justice Scalia, that Congress reasonably could have found that there were difficulties in making this transition.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: The cost of commitment of these people is very high, much higher than standard incarceration.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: I believe the States say in their amicus brief that it's some $65,000 a year per person per year, and -- and the State may feel as though it shouldn't have responsibility over this person--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Was it -- was that a consideration?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: You mentioned that this originated, 4246, with a -- with a committee of judges who said, we have a problem.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Did they--

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: --That is exactly right, Justice Ginsburg, and maybe that's the -- the best answer to Justice Scalia, is history, and it's history on two separate occasions, which this Court has noted.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: It's history when -- when this committee of Federal judges chaired by Calvert Magruder, including Learned Hand, said we have a real problem here with people being let go out of the Federal system and the States not stepping forward and taking responsibility for them.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: And the Court confronted and -- and thought about the exact same problem when Congress passed in 1984 section 4243, which is the civil commitment statute that applies to insanity acquittees, people who are acquitted on the basis of insanity.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Was it -- was that a consideration?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: You mentioned that this originated, 4246, with a -- with a committee of judges who said, we have a problem.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Did they--

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: --That is exactly right, Justice Ginsburg, and maybe that's the -- the best answer to Justice Scalia, is history, and it's history on two separate occasions, which this Court has noted.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: It's history when -- when this committee of Federal judges chaired by Calvert Magruder, including Learned Hand, said we have a real problem here with people being let go out of the Federal system and the States not stepping forward and taking responsibility for them.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: And the Court confronted and -- and thought about the exact same problem when Congress passed in 1984 section 4243, which is the civil commitment statute that applies to insanity acquittees, people who are acquitted on the basis of insanity.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: "Federal courts decried time and again the gaping statutory hole. "

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: that is the hole that -- that existed because people were acquitted on the basis of insanity and -- and States were not willing to step forward and take custody of those people in the way that they would have taken custody of those people if they had been acquitted of insanity in the State court systems.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I must say I'm -- I'm not terribly impressed with -- with the argument--

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: I can tell, Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --the States won't do it.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: No, I--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The States won't do it; therefore, we have to do it.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It has to be done, and therefore the Federal Government steps in and does it.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: --I don't think so, Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: I think, in fact, that -- that Congress on each of these three occasions has limited the civil commitment power only to people who have been -- who are in the custody of the Federal Government and over whom the Federal Government has a distinctive responsibility.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: I will give you an example, Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It has to be done, and therefore the Federal Government steps in and does it.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: --I don't think so, Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: I think, in fact, that -- that Congress on each of these three occasions has limited the civil commitment power only to people who have been -- who are in the custody of the Federal Government and over whom the Federal Government has a distinctive responsibility.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: I will give you an example, Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: I mean, suppose that there was some very contagious form of drug-resistant tuberculosis that had -- had become prevalent in the prison system, and States were not able to deal with that, with quarantining these people upon their release date, and Congress said: You know, the best thing to do is to have the Federal Government act as the appropriate quarantining authority because we don't think that States are able to step up and deal with this problem.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Would anybody say that the Federal Government would not have Article I power to effect that kind of public safety measure?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I -- I notice that in -- in the government's position, you don't argue the Commerce Clause very much, and I -- we've got Morrison v. Brzonkala looking at you and Printz and so forth.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But it -- suppose Congress said there is a class of committable, dangerous sex offenders that are crossing State lines and using interstate facilities, and made those findings.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Would that be sufficient to establish a Federal commitment law?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: --Well, as you say, Justice Kennedy, the government has never argued the Commerce Clause here in the sense that it has never argued that these activities have a substantial effect on interstate commerce, and it hasn't done so because of the Morrison -- the Morrison precedent.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: The Commerce Clause I think is relevant in two ways.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: It's relevant first because, of course, it's often the Commerce Clause that gives rise to the power to criminalize conduct and to punish people for that conduct.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: That's -- that's right.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: And in addition to that, these are the people who are most likely to violate Federal laws based on the Commerce Clause in the future -- most likely to violate such laws because they have done so in the past and because they have mental conditions that make it extremely difficult--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: But isn't it true that this statute applies even if a person has not been a sexual offender in the past?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: --It -- it does, Justice Stevens.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: There have been 103--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: So that argument doesn't take care of that--

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Of those, the Bureau of Prisons has certified only 105 of those, who were also found to have the kind of mental illness that made it reasonably likely that -- that they would continue to commit this -- these kinds of offenses.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: What about release from the Army?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Would that -- would that also -- if I want to turn this -- this person after discharge at -- you know, loose upon the society, could the Federal Government commit that person?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Mr. Chief -- excuse me, Justice Scalia -- I didn't mean to promote you quite so quickly.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Thanks for thinking it was a promotion.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: And I'm sure you didn't.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Justice Scalia, I -- I do think that the military has special responsibilities with respect to those people in it.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: In general, I would say that the relationship between a prisoner and a -- and a jailer is more comprehensive than any other kind of relationship that one can name.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: But I do think that the military relationship approaches that.

context.speaker: G. Alan DuBois
context.text: Because at that point, the government has no live Federal interest.

context.speaker: G. Alan DuBois
context.text: They are -- they have effectuated the power which brought the person into custody.

context.speaker: G. Alan DuBois
context.text: They have fully vindicated the-the criminal law that brought them into -- into the prisons.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --Well, suppose, in Justice Alito's hypothetical, he caught the communicable disease in the prison as a result of poor prison conditions.

context.speaker: G. Alan DuBois
context.text: Well, and I'm sure stuff like that does happen, Justice Kennedy, and, again, the government does, while the person is in the custody of Bureau of Prisons, is entitled to--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy

context.speaker: Madeleine C. Wanslee

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And so, since I don't think there is some kind of constitutional due process error here, and there's clearly jurisdiction over the parties, I guess you are saying there wasn't subject matter jurisdiction, which is a little vague.

context.text: And so I want to know what's the clearest case, strongest for you, where a court has ever said that a failure of some -- of some other court to apply the language of a statute properly, no matter how clear, is a lack of subject matter jurisdiction?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Thomas has our opinion this morning in case 08-1134, United Student Aid Funds versus Espinoza.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: This case comes to us on the writ of certiorari to United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: The bankruptcy code provides that, a debtor in Chapter 13 proceeding may obtain a discharge of certain student loan debts, only if the failure to discharge that debt would impose an undue hardship on the debtor and his dependence.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Something like that.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Okay.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: So, now, I think, well, I go back to Justice Scalia's language of that statute.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And I say, oh, my goodness, why did you pick these three?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I mean, I can easily -- I make up comical examples because they illustrate the point.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: That's not my point.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I don't believe the way you've interpreted the statute that you could or would -- could prosecute what I just made up as a funny example.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: --Right.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But I can make up thousands of examples from the list, and I think Justice Scalia's original point was something like, well, you've taken some words, 28 words that cover 6,000 things, and out of those 6,000 things, you have picked, perhaps randomly, 3 which--

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: Well, I -- I think--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: --you say it covers.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: --defending what the Congress attempted to do.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: But I think that Congress viewed it as a permissible and in some ways clearer way of getting to the result it wanted, to point to the body of case law with the recognition that it was understood in its core aspects to cover what I have just described.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: And--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I thought there was a principle that a citizen is supposed to be able to understand the criminal law that was around even before Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: --I understand that, Justice Breyer--

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: --He's supposed to abstain.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: When he has a conflict of interest, he is supposed to note that conflict and he's supposed to abstain.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: And we argued--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Well, what if a public official -- you said in response to Justice Stevens that this actionable conduct has to benefit the defendant's interest.

context.text: What if his interest is a particular policy contrary to that of his employer?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: In other words, he is a subordinate official.

context.speaker: Kerry A. Scanlon
context.text: This is the most powerful kind of mitigating evidence you can have in this type of case.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Could I take you back to Justice Alito's question?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: As I read the lower court decision, it was saying counsel made a strategic choice not to pursue any further investigation with respect to mental health, correct?

context.speaker: Kerry A. Scanlon
context.text: Correct.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: And they made it on the basis of a number of factors, including the fact that there was testimony that the two senior attorneys said: It's not going to help us if we do or not.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: You may disagree with whether or not a strategic decision was made or not, but if one can view the evidence in any way as the attorney having made the decision, isn't your argument that that decision was unreasonable?

context.speaker: Kerry A. Scanlon
context.text: Of course.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: But isn't that what Justice Alito asked you?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: That's not a dispute with the factual finding that it was a strategic decision.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: That's a dispute with the legal -- the legal -- whether that strategic decision met the legal standard of Strickland.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: That's a dispute with the legal -- the legal -- whether that strategic decision met the legal standard of Strickland.

context.speaker: Kerry A. Scanlon
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So we're back to Justice Alito's question, which is, isn't that a (d)(1) instead of a (d)(2) argument, and we -- the question presented only addressed the strategic decision.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: It didn't address or present the question of the Strickland question of whether that would have been a reasonable strategic decision.

context.speaker: Kerry A. Scanlon
context.text: Your Honor, that is our alternative argument.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I'm talking about (d)(2).

context.speaker: Kerry A. Scanlon
context.text: I think it would -- I think it would apply there, too.

context.speaker: Kerry A. Scanlon
context.text: I think--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Because the problem, as Justice Ginsburg indicated, is that the courts of appeals are looking for guidance as -- as to when we can go into -- into these findings and set them aside.

context.speaker: Kerry A. Scanlon
context.text: --Right.

context.speaker: Kerry A. Scanlon

context.text: That position is what the Court ended up doing in Rice v. Collins, saying that even if we don't answer the question, the State wins.

context.text: And you could do the same thing here, too, that the strategic decision, finding of fact is not unreasonable.

context.text: But we're trying to help the Court find a way to make (e)(1) and (d)(2) work together.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Well, we have one here, and my real objection, I guess -- and it's interesting, I now see the conflict, with Justice Alito's clear explanation of it.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And I -- I suppose the -- the thing I would ask you then is, look, my objection to it, hypothetically, is it's too complicated.

context.text: I agree that our--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor

context.text: --evidence on correctness.

context.speaker: Corey L. Maze
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So, why do you need (e)(1)?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: That's -- that's Justice Breyer's question, as I understand it.

context.speaker: Corey L. Maze
context.text: I agree.

context.speaker: Corey L. Maze
context.text: And, again, my position is just what Justice Alito had said earlier, that's the step-by-step way that we would approach it.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: --jury.

context.text: Not the penalty phase?

context.speaker: Corey L. Maze
context.text: --Correct.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So that's really -- I think that was Justice Stevens' question, which was, what was the strategic basis of a decision not to pursue mental health information when everything you wanted to keep out of the penalty phase would be coming at the sentencing phase anyway?

context.text: Let me see if I'm understanding the question correctly.
